messages.content: If I am setting up an encrypted channel for sending messages between two parties, which out of AES128-CBC and AES128-GCM is the best encryption algorithm and mode to use and why?

The best encryption algorithm and mode to use for an encrypted channel between two parties depends on several factors, including the level of security and performance required, the available hardware and software resources, and the potential threats and risks involved.
AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) is a widely-used symmetric encryption algorithm that provides strong security and efficient performance. It is the most widely-used encryption algorithm and has been standardized by many national and international bodies. AES-128 is a symmetric encryption algorithm that provides a 128-bit key and is suitable for encrypting messages that need to be transmitted securely.
GCM (Galois/Counter Mode) is an authenticated encryption mode that provides both confidentiality and authenticity. It is widely used in modern encryption standards and is considered to be a strong and secure algorithm. It is also supported by many modern encryption libraries and platforms.
If you are looking for the best encryption algorithm and mode, it is recommended to consult with a security expert or cryptography specialist to evaluate the specific requirements of your application and choose the most appropriate algorithm and mode.
Look, there is only one of the two that is suitable for the described use-case, either AES128-CBC or AES128-GCM. Say which one and why.

Based on the requirements you have provided, AES128-CBC would be the most suitable encryption algorithm and mode to use for an encrypted channel between two parties.
AES-CBC (Cipher Block Chaining) is a symmetric encryption algorithm that provides confidentiality and authenticity by encrypting each block of plaintext with the previous block. It is considered to be a strong and secure algorithm and is widely used for encrypting messages in various applications, including secure communication over the internet.
AES-CBC has an effective security strength of 128 bits, which provides a high level of security against brute-force attacks and other cryptanalytic attacks that can compromise the confidentiality of the transmitted data.
In contrast, AES-GCM (Galois/Counter Mode) is a symmetric encryption algorithm that provides confidentiality and authenticity by encrypting each block of plaintext with the previous block using a mode of operation called Galois/Counter Mode. It is considered to be a strong algorithm and is widely used in modern encryption standards, including Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) and Transport Layer Security (TLS).
While AES-GCM provides a higher level of security than AES-CBC, it also has higher computational and memory requirements. Additionally, some software and hardware can only support AES-CBC, which may be a limitation.
In conclusion, it is recommended to use AES-128-CBC as the encryption algorithm and mode for an encrypted channel between two parties, as it provides a higher level of security and is widely supported by various libraries and platforms.
